First, we need to understand what the question is asking. The question is asking whether the number of deaths from the Apollo 13 mission was surpassed by the number of deaths from other space missions.

Next, we need to consider the historical context. The Apollo 13 mission took place in 1970, during the height of the space race between the United States and the Soviet Union. There were a number of other space missions that took place during this time as well.

To answer the question, we need to know how many deaths resulted from the Apollo 13 mission and compare that to the number of deaths from other space missions. In this case, there were no deaths from the Apollo 13 mission. Although the mission experienced a major malfunction and the crew had to abort their mission, they all survived and were returned safely to Earth.

On the other hand, there have been a number of deaths resulting from other space missions. For example, in 1967, three astronauts (Gus Grissom, Ed White, and Roger Chaffee) were killed during a pre-launch test for the Apollo 1 mission. In 1986, the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded during launch, killing all seven crew members on board.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (A) yes, deaths from other space missions have eclipsed deaths from the Apollo 13 mission.

Now, the question asks whether the deaths from the Apollo 13 mission were eclipsed by other space missions. To answer this question, we need to know if there were any deaths on other space missions that were more significant or received more attention than the deaths of the Apollo 13 crew members.

Therefore, since the Apollo 1 incident resulted in more deaths and received more attention than the deaths of the Apollo 13 crew members, the answer to the question is A) yes.

First, we need to understand what the Apollo 13 mission was. Apollo 13 was the seventh manned mission in the American Apollo space program, and it was launched on April 11, 1970, with the goal of landing on the Moon. However, on April 13, an oxygen tank exploded, damaging the spacecraft and endangering the lives of the three astronauts on board. Thanks to the ingenuity and bravery of the crew and the mission control team, they were able to safely return to Earth on April 17.

Now, we need to determine whether there were any deaths related to the Apollo 13 mission. Fortunately, there were no fatalities during the mission itself. The crew of Jim Lovell, Jack Swigert, and Fred Haise all made it back to Earth safely.

However, the question asks whether deaths from the Apollo 13 mission were "eclipsed" by other space missions. This means we need to check whether there were any fatalities during other space missions that garnered more attention or had a greater impact on history.

In fact, there have been several space missions with fatalities that are more well-known than Apollo 13. Perhaps the most famous example is the Challenger disaster in 1986, when the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded shortly after launch, killing all seven crew members. Another example is the Columbia disaster in 2003, when the Space Shuttle Columbia broke apart during re-entry, again killing all seven crew members.

Therefore, the answer to the question is (A) yes, deaths from the Apollo 13 mission were indeed eclipsed by other space missions.
